issues.details: No fire alarm sounded during the Wanchung Court apartment fire, delaying evacuation.
Polystyrene board covering windows ignited quickly, contributing to rapid fire spread.
Bamboo scaffolding allegedly accelerated fire spread and hindered firefighting operations.
Claims that bamboo is not easily combustible and may not have been the primary cause of fire spread.

responses.clarification: Confirmed that no alarm sounded and that authorities will take legal action.
Identified as the main flammable material that ignited and caused glass breakage.
Acknowledged that bamboo and its debris contributed to fire spread and blocked access for firefighters.
Stated that bamboo is harder to ignite than typical wood and that other materials likely caused the fire.

evaluations.opinion: Highlights serious safety lapses in building materials and emergency systems.
Questions the emphasis on bamboo as the main culprit, suggesting other factors.

confirmed_facts: No fire alarm sounded during the incident.
Polystyrene board covering windows ignited quickly.
Bamboo scaffolding was present and obstructed firefighting efforts.
unconfirmed_allegations: Bamboo itself was the primary cause of fire spread.
Other undisclosed materials contributed to ignition.
Management oversight was the sole reason for the use of flammable materials.

timeline.event: Hong Kong began phasing out bamboo scaffolding in favor of metal.
Policy announced to transition to metal scaffolding.
Chris Tang briefing; confirmation of no alarm and flammable materials.
Fire reached 500Â°C; bamboo scaffolding hindered firefighting.
Christoph Krolla comments on bamboo flammability.
